Although the word is no longer in general use, tort suits are the stuff of everyday headlines. More and 
more people injured by exposure to a variety of risks now seek redress (some sort of remedy through the 
courts). Headlines boast of multimillion-dollar jury awards against doctors who bungled operations, 
against newspapers that libeled subjects of stories, and against oil companies that devastate entire 
ecosystems. All are examples of tort suits. 
 
The law of torts developed almost entirely in the common-law courts; that is, statutes passed by 
legislatures were not the source of law that plaintiffs usually relied on. Usually, plaintiffs would rely on the 
common law (judicial decisions). Through thousands of cases, the courts have fashioned a series of rules 
that govern the conduct of individuals in their noncontractual dealings with each other. Through 
contracts, individuals can craft their own rights and responsibilities toward each other. In the absence of 
contracts, tort law holds individuals legally accountable for the consequences of their actions. Those who 
suffer losses at the hands of others can be compensated. 
 
Many acts (like homicide) are both criminal and tortious. But torts and crimes are different, and the 
difference is worth noting. A crime is an act against the people as a whole. Society punishes the murderer; 
it does not usually compensate the family of the victim. Tort law, on the other hand, views the death as a 
private wrong for which damages are owed. In a civil case, the tort victim or his family, not the state, 
brings the action. The judgment against a defendant in a civil tort suit is usually expressed in monetary

Dimensions of Tort: Excuses 
A third element in the law of torts is the excuse for committing an apparent wrong. The law does not 
condemn every act that ultimately results in injury. 
 
One common rule of exculpation is assumption of risk. A baseball fan who sits along the third base line 
close to the infield assumes the risk that a line drive foul ball may fly toward him and strike him. He will 
not be permitted to complain in court that the batter should have been more careful or that management 
should have either warned him or put up a protective barrier. 
 
Another excuse is negligence of the plaintiff. If two drivers are careless and hit each other on the highway, 
some states will refuse to permit either to recover from the other. Still another excuse is consent: two 
boxers in the ring consent to being struck with fists (but not to being bitten on the ear).

Absolute Privilege 
Statements made during the course of judicial proceedings are absolutely privileged, meaning that they 
cannot serve as the basis for a defamation suit. Accurate accounts of judicial or other proceedings are 
absolutely privileged; a newspaper, for example, may pass on the slanderous comments of a judge in 
court. “Judicial” is broadly construed to include most proceedings of administrative bodies of the 
government. The Constitution exempts members of Congress from suits for libel or slander for any 
statements made in connection with legislative business. The courts have constructed a similar privilege 
for many executive branch officials. 
 
Qualified Privilege 
Absolute privileges pertain to those in the public sector. A narrower privilege exists for private citizens. In 
general, a statement that would otherwise be actionable is held to be justified if made in a reasonable 
manner and for a reasonable purpose. Thus you may warn a friend to beware of dealing with a third 
person, and if you had reason to believe that what you said was true, you are privileged to issue the 
warning, even though false. Likewise, an employee may warn an employer about the conduct or character 
of a fellow or prospective employee, and a parent may complain to a school board about the competence 
or conduct of a child’s teacher. There is a line to be drawn, however, and a defendant with nothing but an 
idle interest in the matter (an “officious intermeddler”) must take the risk that his information is wrong.

Invasion of Privacy 
The right of privacy—the right “to be let alone”—did not receive judicial recognition until the twentieth 
century, and its legal formulation is still evolving. In fact there is no single right of privacy. Courts and 
commentators have discerned at least four different types of interests: (1) the right to control the 
appropriation of your name and picture for commercial purposes, (2) the right to be free of intrusion on 
your “personal space” or seclusion, (3) freedom from public disclosure of embarrassing and intimate facts 
of your personal life, and (4) the right not to be presented in a “false light.” 
 
Appropriation of Name or Likeness 
The earliest privacy interest recognized by the courts was appropriation of name or likeness: someone else 
placing your photograph on a billboard or cereal box as a model or using your name as endorsing a 
product or in the product name. A New York statute makes it a misdemeanor to use the name, portrait, or 
picture of any person for advertising purposes or for the purposes of trade (business) without first 
obtaining written consent. The law also permits the aggrieved person to sue and to recover damages for 
unauthorized profits and also to have the court enjoin (judicially block) any further unauthorized use of 
the plaintiff’s name, likeness, or image. This is particularly useful to celebrities. 
 
Because the publishing and advertising industries are concentrated heavily in New York, the statute plays 
an important part in advertising decisions made throughout the country. Deciding what “commercial” or 
“trade” purposes are is not always easy. Thus a newsmagazine may use a baseball player’s picture on its

Assumption of Risk 
Risk of injury pervades the modern world, and plaintiffs should not win a lawsuit simply because they 
took a risk and lost. The law provides, therefore, that when a person knowingly takes a risk, he or she 
must suffer the consequences. 
 
The assumption of risk doctrine comes up in three ways. The plaintiff may have formally agreed with the 
defendant before entering a risky situation that he will relieve the defendant of liability should injury 
occur. (“You can borrow my car if you agree not to sue me if the brakes fail, because they’re worn and I 
haven’t had a chance to replace them.”) Or the plaintiff may have entered into a relationship with the 
defendant knowing that the defendant is not in a position to protect him from known risks (the fan who is 
hit by a line drive in a ballpark). Or the plaintiff may act in the face of a risky situation known in advance 
to have been created by the defendant’s negligence (failure to leave, while there was an opportunity to do 
so, such as getting into an automobile when the driver is known to be drunk). 
 
The difficulty in many cases is to determine the dividing line between subjectivity and objectivity. If the 
plaintiff had no actual knowledge of the risk, he cannot be held to have assumed it. On the other hand, it is

community knowledge (a “but you should have known” test) in many situations. When the plaintiff has no 
real alternative, however, assumption of risk fails as a defense (e.g., a landlord who negligently fails to 
light the exit to the street cannot claim that his tenants assumed the risk of using it). 
 
At the turn of the century, courts applied assumption of risk in industrial cases to bar relief to workers 
injured on the job. They were said to assume the risk of dangerous conditions or equipment. This rule has 
been abolished by workers’ compensation statutes in most states.

qa_pairs.question: What is the principle behind the rule of comparative negligence and how does it work in practice?
qa_pairs.answer: The principle behind the rule of comparative negligence is that damages are apportioned according to the defendant's degree of culpability. In practice, this means that if a plaintiff sustains a $100,000 injury but is found to be 20% responsible, the defendant would only be liable for $80,000 in damages. This approach aims to fairly distribute the financial burden based on each party's fault level.

qa_pairs.question: How does the assumption of risk doctrine function in different scenarios and what factors influence its application?
qa_pairs.answer: The assumption of risk doctrine operates in various scenarios. It can be formalized through an agreement where the plaintiff accepts liability in exchange for the use of something potentially hazardous, such as borrowing a car with known issues. Alternatively, it applies when the plaintiff knowingly enters a situation with known risks, like attending a baseball game aware of the inherent danger of flying balls. Additionally, it can occur when the plaintiff chooses to engage in a risky activity created by the defendant's negligence, such as entering a vehicle driven by an intoxicated driver. The application of this doctrine often hinges on subjective and objective standards; courts may consider community knowledge and whether the plaintiff had actual awareness of the risk. However, in situations where the plaintiff has no real choice, such as when a landlord negligently fails to illuminate an exit, assumption of risk cannot serve as a defense. The key factor is determining the line between subjective perception and objective reality in understanding the risk involved.

Act of God 
Technically, the rule that no one is responsible for an “act of God,” or force majeure as it is sometimes 
called, is not an excuse but a defense premised on a lack of causation. If a force of nature caused the harm, 
then the defendant was not negligent in the first place. A marina, obligated to look after boats moored at 
its dock, is not liable if a sudden and fierce storm against which no precaution was possible destroys 
someone’s vessel. However, if it is foreseeable that harm will flow from a negligent condition triggered by 
a natural event, then there is liability. For example, a work crew failed to remove residue explosive gas 
from an oil barge. Lightning hit the barge, exploded the gas, and injured several workmen. The plaintiff 
recovered damages against the company because the negligence consisted in the failure to guard against 
any one of a number of chance occurrences that could ignite the gas. [3] 
 
Vicarious Liability 
Liability for negligent acts does not always end with the one who was negligent. Under certain 
circumstances, the liability is imputed to others. For example, an employer is responsible for the 
negligence of his employees if they were acting in the scope of employment. This rule of vicarious liability 
is often called respondeat superior, meaning that the higher authority must respond to claims brought 
against one of its agents. Respondeat superior is not limited to the employment relationship but extends 
to a number of other agency relationships as well.

Legislatures in many states have enacted laws that make people vicariously liable for acts of certain people 
with whom they have a relationship, though not necessarily one of agency. It is common, for example, for 
the owner of an automobile to be liable for the negligence of one to whom the owner lends the car. So-
called dram shop statutes place liability on bar and tavern owners and others who serve too much alcohol 
to one who, in an intoxicated state, later causes injury to others. In these situations, although the injurious 
act of the drinker stemmed from negligence, the one whom the law holds vicariously liable (the bartender) 
is not himself necessarily negligent—the law is holding him strictly liable, and to this concept we now 
turn.

qa_pairs.question: What does the abolition of the assumption of risk rule mean for injured workers in most states?
qa_pairs.answer: The abolition of the assumption of risk rule means that injured workers in most states are no longer required to prove that they assumed the risk of dangerous conditions or equipment when they were injured on the job. Instead, workers' compensation statutes provide a framework for injured workers to receive compensation without needing to demonstrate fault or contributory negligence on their part.

qa_pairs.question: How does the concept of 'act of God' affect liability in cases involving natural disasters, and what are the conditions under which liability can be established despite such events?
qa_pairs.answer: The concept of 'act of God' generally serves as a defense that absolves defendants from liability for harm caused by natural forces beyond human control, as it implies that the defendant was not negligent. However, liability can still be established if it is foreseeable that harm would result from a negligent condition triggered by a natural event. For instance, if a work crew fails to remove explosive gas from an oil barge, and a lightning strike subsequently causes an explosion, the company may be held liable due to its negligence in failing to prevent potential hazards that could lead to accidents, even though the actual ignition was due to an unforeseeable act of nature.

qa_pairs.question: What conditions must be met for a plaintiff to succeed in a strict liability claim under Section 402(a)?
qa_pairs.answer: For a plaintiff to succeed in a strict liability claim under Section 402(a), they must meet several conditions. First, the plaintiff must demonstrate that the product had a defective condition when it left the seller's hands. This defect must have caused physical harm to the plaintiff either to themselves or to their property. Additionally, the defective condition must be the direct cause of the injury or damage. A key aspect of strict liability is that it holds the defendant responsible regardless of whether they exercised all possible care, meaning the plaintiff does not need to prove fault or negligence.

qa_pairs.question: What are some common defenses available to defendants in strict liability cases involving product defects?
qa_pairs.answer: Defendants in strict liability cases involving product defects can rely on several common defenses. These include assumption of risk, where the plaintiff knowingly accepted the risks associated with the product's use; product misuse, which applies when the plaintiff used the product in an unforeseeable and unconventional manner; and the knowledgeable-user defense, particularly relevant in cases where the plaintiff is aware of potential risks but still uses the product. Other defenses may involve arguing that the product's danger was a common knowledge, thereby negating the manufacturer's responsibility. Contributory negligence and comparative negligence are also often raised, suggesting that the plaintiff's own actions contributed to the injury.

qa_pairs.question: In the context of negligence, how does the 'risk reasonably to be perceived' influence the duty to be obeyed?
qa_pairs.answer: The 'risk reasonably to be perceived' plays a crucial role in determining the duty of care that an individual or entity must adhere to. This principle means that the likelihood of harm or damage must be considered in light of what a reasonable person would anticipate under similar circumstances. Essentially, if a person or organization can foresee a potential risk to others, they have a legal obligation to take reasonable steps to prevent that risk from materializing. For example, in the case of operating a speedway or a race course, the inherent risks are widely understood and accepted, thus the duty of care is less stringent compared to situations where unforeseen dangers could arise, such as shooting a missile or launching fireworks. The perception of risk is subjective and depends on the specific context and the actions of those involved. However, once a risk is identified, the duty to mitigate that risk becomes clear, even if the path the destructive force takes is not entirely predictable.

qa_pairs.question: What legal implications arise when a destructive act, despite being known to be potentially harmful, results in unintended injury to a third party?
qa_pairs.answer: When a destructive act, such as shooting a missile or launching fireworks, is known to be potentially harmful but still results in unintended injury to a third party, the legal implications can be complex and multifaceted. In such scenarios, the person or entity responsible for the act may not always be relieved of liability, even if the path the destructive force took was unexpected. The concept of 'negligence' comes into play here, which is defined in terms of the natural or probable consequences of an act. The key point is that if the harm was not intentional, the injured party must demonstrate that the act posed a significant and obvious danger, making it necessary to protect oneself from it. This means that the injured party must prove that the act had 'possibilities of danger so many and apparent as to entitle him to be protected against the doing of it,' even if the harm was unintended. In other words, the responsible party must have foreseen the potential for harm and taken appropriate precautions to prevent it, thereby fulfilling their duty of care. If these conditions are met, the responsible party may still face legal consequences, even if the exact outcome was unforeseeable.

The principles of tort law pervade modern society because they spell out the duties of care that we owe

qa_pairs.question: Why would certain activities be deemed ultrahazardous or abnormally dangerous so that strict liability is imposed?
qa_pairs.answer: Certain activities are deemed ultrahazardous or abnormally dangerous because they pose a high risk of causing severe harm or damage to people or property. These activities typically involve the use of highly volatile substances, complex machinery, or situations where human error can lead to catastrophic consequences. For instance, the public display of fireworks, as seen in the case, involves launching rockets into the air with the intent of creating explosions in the presence of large crowds. This creates a substantial risk of serious personal injury or property damage due to potential malfunctions or misdirections. By imposing strict liability, the law aims to ensure that those responsible for these activities have adequate incentives to take all necessary precautions to prevent accidents, thereby protecting the public from the inherent risks associated with such activities.

qa_pairs.question: Assume that the fireworks were negligently manufactured in China. Should Klein's only remedy be against the Chinese company, as Pyrodyne argues? Why or why not?
qa_pairs.answer: Klein's remedy should not be limited to the Chinese manufacturer even if the fireworks were negligently manufactured there. The court's decision in this case highlights that strict liability applies when an abnormally dangerous activity causes harm, regardless of whether the harm was caused by a specific negligent act. In this scenario, the public display of fireworks was considered an abnormally dangerous activity, and the court ruled that Pyrodyne, the entity conducting the display, is strictly liable for the resulting injuries. This means that Klein can seek compensation from Pyrodyne directly, irrespective of the manufacturer's negligence. The court's rejection of Pyrodyne's argument underscores the principle that strict liability does not depend on the existence of an intervening cause of negligence; rather, it focuses on the defendant's role in the abnormally dangerous activity. Therefore, Klein has the right to pursue a claim against Pyrodyne for his injuries, ensuring that he receives the necessary compensation without being restricted to the manufacturer alone.

The Restatements (others exist in the fields of torts, agency, conflicts of laws, judgments, property, 
restitution, security, and trusts) are detailed analyses of the decided cases in the field. These analyses are 
made with an eye to discerning the various principles that have emerged from the courts, and to the 
maximum extent possible, the Restatements declare the law as the courts have determined it to be. The 
Restatements, guided by a Reporter (the director of the project) and a staff of legal scholars, go through 
several so-called “tentative” drafts—sometimes as many as fifteen or twenty—and are screened by various 
committees within the American Law Institute before they are eventually published as final documents. 
 
The Restatement of Contracts won prompt respect in the courts and has been cited in innumerable cases. 
The Restatements are not authoritative, in the sense that they are not actual judicial precedents, but they 
are nevertheless weighty interpretive texts, and judges frequently look to them for guidance. They are as 
close to “black letter” rules of law as exist anywhere in the American legal system for judge-made 
(common) law.

An express contract is one in which the terms are spelled out directly; the parties to an express 
contract, whether written or oral, are conscious that they are making an enforceable agreement. For 
example, an agreement to purchase your neighbor’s car for $500 and to take title next Monday is an 
express contract. 
 
Implied Contract 
An implied contract is one that is inferred from the actions of the parties. Although no discussion of 
terms took place, an implied contract exists if it is clear from the conduct of both parties that they 
intended there be one. A delicatessen patron who asks for a “turkey sandwich to go” has made a contract 
and is obligated to pay when the sandwich is made. By ordering the food, the patron is implicitly agreeing 
to the price, whether posted or not. 
 
Contract Implied in Law: Quasi-contract 
Both express and implied contracts embody an actual agreement of the parties. A quasi-contract, by 
contrast, is an obligation said to be ‘‘imposed by law” in order to avoid unjust enrichment of one person at 
the expense of another. In fact, a quasi-contract is not a contract at all; it is a fiction that the courts 
created to prevent injustice. Suppose, for example, that a carpenter mistakenly believes you have hired 
him to repair your porch; in fact, it is your neighbor who has hired him. One Saturday morning he arrives 
at your doorstep and begins to work. Rather than stop him, you let him proceed, pleased at the prospect of 
having your porch fixed for free (since you have never talked to the carpenter, you figure you need not pay 
his bill). Although it is true there is no contract, the law implies a contract for the value of the work. 
 
 
Mutuality 
The garden-variety contract is one in which the parties make mutual promises. Each is both promisor and 
promisee; that is, each pledges to do something and each is the recipient of such a pledge. This type of 
contract is called a bilateral contract. But mutual promises are not necessary to constitute a 
contract. Unilateral contracts, in which only one party makes a promise, are equally valid but depend

qa_pairs.answer: An express contract stands out because its terms are explicitly stated, either in writing or through direct verbal communication between the parties involved. The parties are fully aware of the terms and understand that this agreement can be legally enforced. For instance, an agreement where you decide to buy your neighbor's car for $500 with the stipulation that the transfer of ownership occurs next Monday is a classic example of an express contract. This clarity in terms sets it apart from implied contracts and quasi-contracts, where the existence of a contract may be inferred from the actions or circumstances of the parties, rather than explicit statements.

The carpenter starts working, and the homeowner, unaware of the mistake, allows the work to continue. Despite the absence of an actual contract, the law imposes a quasi-contract to prevent the carpenter from being unjustly enriched at the homeowner's expense. The core of a legal contract is the agreement between the parties. That is not merely a matter of 
convenience; it is at the heart of our received philosophical and psychological beliefs. As the great student 
of contract law, Samuel Williston, put it: 
 
It was a consequence of the emphasis laid on the ego and the individual will that the formation of 
a contract should seem impossible unless the wills of the parties concurred. Accordingly we find 
at the end of the eighteenth century, and the beginning of the nineteenth century, the prevalent 
idea that there must be a “meeting of the minds” (a new phrase) in order to form a contract. 
(1921, p. 365) 
 
Although agreements may take any form, including unspoken conduct between the parties (UCC Section 
2-204(1)), they are usually structured in terms of an offer and an acceptance. Note, however, that not 
every agreement, in the broadest sense of the word, need consist of an offer and acceptance, and it is 
entirely possible, therefore, for two persons to reach agreement without forming a contract. For example,

Servant 
The final category of agent is the servant. Until the early nineteenth century, any employee whose work 
duties were subject to an employer’s control was called a servant; we would not use that term so broadly 
in modern English. The Restatement (Second) of Agency, Section 2, defines a servant as “an agent 
employed by a master [employer] to perform service in his affairs whose physical conduct in the 
performance of the service is controlled or is subject to the right to control by the master.”

distinction made between the status of a servant and that of an independent contractor. According to 
the Restatement (Second) of Agency, Section 2, “an independent contractor is a person who contracts 
with another to do something for him but who is not controlled by the other nor subject to the other’s 
right to control with respect to his physical conduct in the performance of the undertaking.” As the name 
implies, the independent contractor is legally autonomous. A plumber salaried to a building contractor is 
an employee and agent of the contractor. But a plumber who hires himself out to repair pipes in people’s 
homes is an independent contractor. If you hire a lawyer to settle a dispute, that person is not your 
employee or your servant; she is an independent contractor. The terms “agent” and “independent

qa_pairs.answer: According to the Restatement (Second) of Agency, a servant is defined as 'an agent employed by a master [employer] to perform service in his affairs whose physical conduct in the performance of the service is controlled or is subject to the right to control by the master.' qa_pairs.question: How does the classification of an individual as either an independent contractor or a servant affect their legal standing and responsibilities?
qa_pairs.answer: The classification of an individual as either an independent contractor or a servant can have significant implications for their legal standing and responsibilities. An employee (servant) is considered an agent of the employer and is subject to the employer's control over their work, which includes taxation, workers' compensation, and liability insurance. Employers must withhold income taxes from employees' paychecks and provide them with workers' compensation coverage if they get injured on the job. Additionally, employers are typically responsible for providing health and safety protections and ensuring compliance with labor laws. In contrast, an independent contractor is legally autonomous and is not subject to the same level of control by the hiring party. This means that they are responsible for their own taxes, workers' compensation, and other insurance needs. They may also face different liability considerations, as they are not covered by the employer's insurance policies in the event of accidents or disputes related to their work.

Agency Created by Operation of Law 
Most agencies are made by contract, but agency also may arise impliedly or apparently. 
 
Implied Agency 
In areas of social need, courts have declared an agency to exist in the absence of an agreement. The agency 
relationship then is said to have been implied “by operation of law.” Children in most states may purchase 
necessary items—food or medical services—on the parent’s account. Long-standing social policy deems it 
desirable for the head of a family to support his dependents, and the courts will put the expense on the 
family head in order to provide for the dependents’ welfare. The courts achieve this result by supposing 
the dependent to be the family head’s agent, thus allowing creditors to sue the family head for the debt. 
 
Implied agencies also arise where one person behaves as an agent would and the “principal,” knowing that 
the “agent” is behaving so, acquiesces, allowing the person to hold himself out as an agent. Such are the 
basic facts in Weingart v. Directoire Restaurant, Inc. in Section 9.3.1 "Creation of Agency: Liability of

The principal is liable on an agent’s contract only if the agent was authorized by the principal to make the 
contract. Such authority is express, implied, or apparent. Express means made in words, orally or in 
writing; implied means the agent has authority to perform acts incidental to or reasonably necessary to 
carrying out the transaction for which she has express authority. Apparent authority arises where the principal 
gives the third party reason to believe that the agent had authority. The reasonableness of the third party’s 
belief is based on all the circumstances—all the facts. Even if the agent has no authority, the principal may, 
after the fact, ratify the contract made by the agent.

qa_pairs.question: Why is the concept of implied authority crucial in business operations?
qa_pairs.answer: The concept of implied authority is crucial in business operations because it allows for flexibility and efficiency in day-to-day transactions. Implied authority implies that an agent has the authority to perform acts that are incidental to or reasonably necessary for carrying out the specific transaction for which they have express authority. This means that while the principal might not have explicitly stated that the agent could perform certain tasks, the nature of their work and the context of their interaction with third parties can imply such authority. This is particularly important in business situations where rapid decision-making and quick actions are often required, and formal authorization cannot always be obtained in time. It ensures that businesses can operate smoothly and that third parties can rely on the actions of agents who are acting within the scope of their duties, even if the exact scope wasn't formally defined.

Ordinarily, an individual or a company is not vicariously liable for the tortious acts of independent 
contractors. The plumber who rushes to a client’s house to repair a leak and causes a traffic accident does 
not subject the homeowner to liability. But there are exceptions to the rule. Generally, these exceptions 
fall into a category of duties that the law deems nondelegable. In some situations, one person is obligated 
to provide protection to or care for another. The failure to do so results in liability whether or not the 
harm befell the other because of an independent contractor’s wrongdoing. Thus a homeowner has a duty 
to ensure that physical conditions in and around the home are not unreasonably dangerous. If the owner 
hires an independent contracting firm to dig a sewer line and the contractor negligently fails to guard 
passersby against the danger of falling into an open trench, the homeowner is liable because the duty of

care in this instance cannot be delegated. (The contractor is, of course, liable to the homeowner for any 
damages paid to an injured passerby.) 
 
Liability for Agent’s Intentional Torts 
In the nineteenth century, a principal was rarely held liable for intentional wrongdoing by the agent if the 
principal did not command the act complained of. The thought was that one could never infer authority to 
commit a willfully wrongful act. Today, liability for intentional torts is imputed to the principal if the 
agent is acting to further the principal’s business. See the very disturbing Lyon v. Carey in Section 10.4.2 
"Employer’s Liability for Employee’s Intentional Torts: Scope of Employment". 
Deviations from Employment 
The general rule is that a principal is liable for torts only if the servant committed them “in the scope of 
employment.” But determining what this means is not easy. 
 
The “Scope of Employment” Problem 
It may be clear that the person causing an injury is the agent of another. But a principal cannot be 
responsible for every act of an agent. If an employee is following the letter of his instructions, it will be 
easy to determine liability. But suppose an agent deviates in some way from his job. The classic test of 
liability was set forth in an 1833 English case, Joel v. Morrison. [1] The plaintiff was run over on a highway 
by a speeding cart and horse. The driver was the employee of another, and inside was a fellow employee.

These exceptions arise when one person is obligated to provide protection to or care for another, such as a homeowner ensuring that physical conditions in and around the home are not unreasonably dangerous. In the example given, if a homeowner hires an independent contracting firm to dig a sewer line and the contractor negligently fails to guard passersby against the danger of falling into an open trench, the homeowner would be liable because the duty of care in this instance cannot be delegated.

Torts of Family Members 
At common law, the husband was liable for the torts of his wife, not because she was considered an agent 
but because she was considered to be an extension of him. “Husband and wife were only one person in 
law,” [3] says Holmes, and any act of the wife was supposed to have been done at the husband’s direction 
(to which Mr. Dickens’s Mr. Bumble responded, in the memorable line, “If the law supposes that, the law 
is a ass—a idiot” [4]). This ancient view has been abrogated by statute or by court ruling in all the states, so 
that now a wife is solely responsible for her own torts unless she in fact serves as her husband’s agent. 
 
Unlike wives, children are not presumed at common law to be agents or extensions of the father so that 
normally parents are not vicariously liable for their children’s torts. However, they can be held liable for 
failing to control children known to be dangerous. 
 
Most states have statutorily changed the common-law rule, making parents responsible for willful or 
malicious tortious acts of their children whether or not they are known to be mischief-makers. Thus the

unemancipated minor who resides with such parent or legal guardian is liable for actual damages for the 
willful or malicious acts of such minor which cause injury to a person or property.” [5] Several other states 
impose a monetary limit on such liability.

There are certain types of conduct that statutes or regulation attempt to control by placing the burden of 
liability on those presumably in a position to prevent the unwanted conduct. An example is the 
“Dramshop Act,” which in many states subjects the owner of a bar to liability if the bar continues to serve

qa_pairs.question: In what situations can an employer be held liable for an employee’s criminal acts, and how does this differ from vicarious liability for torts?

For criminal acts, the employer's liability may arise due to putting the employee up to the crime or having knowledge of the criminal activity. It makes sense that an agent should be liable for her own torts; it would be a bad social policy indeed if a 
person could escape tort liability based on her own fault merely because she acted in an agency capacity. It 
also makes sense that—as is the general rule—an agent is not liable on contracts she makes on the 
principal’s behalf; the agent is not a party to a contract made by the agent on behalf of the principal. No 
public policy would be served by imposing liability, and in many cases it would not make sense. Suppose 
an agent contracts to buy $25 million of rolled aluminum for a principal, an airplane manufacturer. The 
agent personally could not reasonably perform such contract, and it is not intended by the parties that she 
should be liable. (Although the rule is different in England, where an agent residing outside the country is 
liable even if it is clear that he is signing in an agency capacity.) But there are three exceptions to this rule: 
(1) if the agent is undisclosed or partially disclosed, (2) if the agent lacks authority or exceeds it, or (3) if 
the agent entered into the contract in a personal capacity. We consider each situation.

qa_pairs.answer: An agent would be considered as an undisclosed or partially disclosed principal when they do not inform the person with whom they are negotiating that they are acting on behalf of a principal. In the case of an 'undisclosed principal,' the agent does not mention the principal's identity, while in the case of a 'partially disclosed principal,' the agent tells the other party that they are acting as an agent but does not disclose the principal's name. This can affect liability in a contract because under these circumstances, the agent might be held liable for the contract if the other party is unaware of the principal's existence or identity. For instance, in the hypothetical example provided, Betty and Clem act as undisclosed and partially disclosed agents respectively, meaning they could potentially be held liable for the contracts they enter into if the landowners later discover the true identity of the principal.

qa_pairs.question: In the context of Lyon v. Carey, what was the employer's liability for the intentional torts committed by the employee, and how did the court determine the scope of employment?
qa_pairs.answer: In the context of Lyon v. Carey, the employer was held liable for the intentional torts committed by the employee, Michael Carey, during his employment. The court determined that the assault and rape committed by Carey were within the scope of his employment. The factors considered included the nature of the job, the timing of the incident, and whether the act was performed in furtherance of the employer's business. The court found that the assault was closely related to Carey's job duties, as he was a deliveryman for the company and the incident occurred while he was on the job. This decision underscores the principle that employers can be held liable for the intentional torts committed by their employees if the acts are within the scope of employment, even if they were not intended to benefit the employer directly. The court's determination hinged on the fact that the act was committed during work hours and in the course of Carey's assigned tasks, thereby satisfying the necessary conditions for liability under the doctrine of respondeat superior.

qa_pairs.question: What are the key differences between the Uniform Partnership Act (UPA) and the Revised Uniform Partnership Act (RUPA) in terms of when they were set out for states to adopt?
qa_pairs.answer: The Uniform Partnership Act (UPA) was set out for states to adopt in 1997, while the Revised Uniform Partnership Act (RUPA) was promulgated for state adoption in 2001. qa_pairs.question: How does the partnership act function as the 'default position' and which types of partnerships are most likely to benefit from adopting either UPA or RUPA?
qa_pairs.answer: The partnership act functions as the 'default position' because it provides a set of rules and regulations that govern partnerships in the absence of a specific partnership agreement. This means that if partners do not establish a detailed partnership agreement, the law will automatically apply these default rules. UPA and RUPA are particularly important for general partnerships, as they offer a comprehensive framework for defining the rights, responsibilities, and obligations of partners. These acts cover various aspects such as partnership formation, management, profits and losses, and dissolution, making them indispensable for ensuring clarity and fairness among partners in a general partnership setting.

Specific Issues of Concern 
In forming a partnership, three of these items merit special attention. And note again that if the parties do 
not provide for these in their agreement, RUPA will do it for them as the default. 
 
Who Can Be a Partner? 
As discussed earlier in this chapter, a partnership is not limited to a direct association between human 
beings but may also include an association between other entities, such as corporations or even 
partnerships themselves. [1] Family members can be partners, and partnerships between parents and 
minor children are lawful, although a partner who is a minor may disaffirm the agreement. 
 
Written versus Oral Agreements 
If the business cannot be performed within one year from the time that the agreement is entered into, the 
partnership agreement should be in writing to avoid invalidation under the Statute of Frauds. Most 
partnerships have no fixed term, however, and are partnerships “at will” and therefore not covered by the 
Statute of Frauds. 
 
Validity of the Partnership Name 
Able, Baker, and Carr decide that it makes good business sense to choose an imposing, catchy, and well-
known name for their dealership—General Motors Corporation. There are two reasons why they cannot 
do so. First, their business is a partnership, not a corporation, and should not be described as one. 
Second, the name is deceptive because it is the name of an existing business. Furthermore, if not 
registered, the name would violate the assumed or fictitious name statutes of most states. These require 
that anyone doing business under a name other than his real name register the name, together with the 
names and addresses of the proprietors, in some public office. (Often, the statutes require the proprietors 
to publish this information in the newspapers when the business is started.) As Loomis v. 
Whitehead in Section 11.3.2 "Creation of a Partnership: Registering the Name" shows, if a business fails to 
comply with the statute, it could find that it will be unable to file suit to enforce its contracts.

qa_pairs.answer: Joint venturers are fiduciaries toward one another, which means they owe each other a duty of loyalty and care. qa_pairs.question: How does liability work in a joint venture and what happens if the joint venture forms a corporation?
qa_pairs.answer: In a joint venture, liability is generally unlimited, meaning that each partner can be held personally responsible for the debts and obligations of the venture. However, if two or more businesses form a joint venture to carry out a specific task and incorporate the joint venture, then the resulting business becomes subject to corporation law, and the liability is limited to the assets of the corporation. In this scenario, the joint venture is no longer governed by the laws of partnership but rather by the laws governing corporations, which typically provide shareholders with limited liability protection against personal financial loss due to the corporation's actions.

Duty of Obedience 
The partnership is a contractual relationship among the partners; they are all agents and principals of 
each other. Expressly or impliedly that means no partner can disobey the partnership agreement or fail to 
follow any properly made partnership decision. This includes the duty to act within the authority 
expressly or impliedly given in the partnership agreement, and a partner is responsible to the other 
partners for damages or losses arising from unauthorized activities. 
 
Duty to Inform Copartners 
As in the agency relationship, a partner is expected to inform copartners of notices and matters coming to 
her attention that would be of interest to the partnership. 
 
Duty to Account 
The partnership—and necessarily the partners—have a duty to allow copartners and their agents access to 
the partnership’s books and records and to provide “any information concerning the partnership’s 
business and affairs reasonably required for the proper exercise of the partner’s rights and duties under 
the partnership agreement [or this Act].” [7] The fiduciary standard is imposed upon the duty to account 
for “it any property, profit, or benefit derived by [a] partner,” as noted in RUPA Section 404. [8]

When a partner joins a partnership, she is expected to make a capital contribution to the firm; this may be

provides that “the partnership must reimburse a partner for an advance of funds beyond the amount of

Section 401(d) of RUPA provides that “a partner is not entitled to remuneration for services performed for

sharing the profits, not by a salary or wages. 
 
Right to Management 
All partners are entitled to share equally in the management and conduct of the business, unless the 
partnership agreement provides otherwise. [12] The partnership agreement could be structured to delegate 
more decision-making power to one class of partners (senior partners) than to others (junior partners), or 
it may give more voting weight to certain individuals. For example, perhaps those with the most 
experience will, for the first four years after a new partner is admitted, have more voting weight than the 
new partner.

trust and confidence between (or among) the parties; in both the poor judgment, negligence, or

Partners’ Personal Liability for Torts 
Of course, a person is always liable for his own torts. All partners are also liable for any partner’s tort 
committed in the scope of partnership business under agency law, and this liability is—again—personal 
and unlimited, subject to RUPA’s requirement that the judgment creditor exhaust the partnership’s assets 
before going after the separate assets of the partners. The partner who commits a tort or breach of trust 
must indemnify the partnership for losses paid to the third party. [9] 
Liability for Crimes 
Criminal liability is generally personal to the miscreant. Nonparticipating copartners are ordinarily not 
liable for crimes if guilty intent is an element. When guilty intent is not an element, as in certain 
regulatory offenses, all partners may be guilty of an act committed by a partner in the course of the 
business. 
 
Liability for Taxes 
Corporate income gets taxed twice under federal law: once to the corporation and again to the 
shareholders who receive income as dividends. However, the partnership’s income “passes through” the 
partnership and is distributed to the partners under the conduit theory. When partners get income 
from the firm they have to pay tax on it, but the partnership pays no tax (it files an information return). 
This is perceived to be a significant advantage of the partnership form.

qa_pairs.answer: The passage indicates that while partners in a partnership are personally liable for the debts and torts of the partnership, they are only liable up to the extent of their damages. qa_pairs.question: How does the passage explain the taxation advantages of the partnership form over corporations?
qa_pairs.answer: The passage explains that the partnership form offers a significant tax advantage over corporations because of the 'conduit theory'. Under this theory, the partnership's income is not taxed at the entity level; instead, it passes through to the partners, who then pay taxes on their share of the income. This means that the partnership itself does not pay any income tax, and the partners only pay tax on their individual shares of the partnership's income. In contrast, corporate income is taxed at both the corporate level and the shareholder level when distributed as dividends, resulting in double taxation. Thus, the partnership form allows for a more efficient flow of income and reduces the overall tax burden on the partners.

qa_pairs.question: What happens to the partnership's business after it has been dissolved?
qa_pairs.answer: After a partnership has been dissolved, it can follow one of two paths. It can either continue to operate as a new partnership or it can wind up its business and cease operations. The continuation of the business as a new partnership requires an agreement among the remaining partners, which could be part of the original partnership agreement or formed after dissolution, preferably in writing though it might also be oral. Under the Uniform Partnership Act (UPA), the remaining partners have the right to carry on the business under specific conditions such as when the dissolution was against the agreement, a partner was expelled, or all partners agreed to continue. However, if the former partner dies or quits the firm, the non-continuing partner or their legal representative is entitled to an accounting and to receive the value of the partnership interest, less damages for wrongful dissolution. In cases where a partner leaves and a new one joins, the partnership might need to borrow money to pay the former partner or their estate, often using proceeds from a life insurance policy that covers the life of each partner.

qa_pairs.question: How does the Uniform Partnership Act address the situation where a partner becomes bankrupt or the business becomes unlawful to carry on?
qa_pairs.answer: According to the Uniform Partnership Act (UPA), no partner can bind the partnership if it has dissolved due to becoming unlawful to carry on the business or if the partner seeking to exercise authority has become bankrupt. This means that once a partnership dissolves under these circumstances, the remaining partners cannot use the partnership name or assets to conduct business unless they form a new partnership with a different agreement. The UPA ensures that the partnership is not held liable for actions taken by a bankrupt partner after dissolution, thereby protecting the integrity and continuity of the business entity post-dissolution.

qa_pairs.question: What liability does Graham face if she joins a general partnership with Follis and Hawthorne, where Follis causes a $100,000 accident and declares bankruptcy, and the partnership's assets are insufficient to cover the damages?
qa_pairs.answer: Graham is not correct in her assertion that she is liable for only $20,000 of the $100,000 in damages. Under the Uniform Partnership Act (UPA), partners in a general partnership are jointly and severally liable for the partnership's debts and obligations, including tortious acts committed by any partner during the course of partnership business. This means that each partner can be held fully responsible for the entire amount of the debt, regardless of the agreed-upon percentage of loss sharing. Therefore, even though Graham agreed to bear 20% of the partnership's losses, she remains personally liable for the full $100,000 in damages due to her joint and several liability as a partner.

qa_pairs.question: If Kelly initially agreed to join a partnership with Ingersoll and Jackson but later changed his mind and took no action to prevent a public notice of his impending partnership from being published, can he still be held liable as a partner when a creditor extends credit to the partnership based on the notice?
qa_pairs.answer: Kelly can indeed be held liable as a partner despite changing his mind about joining the partnership. According to the facts presented, Kelly agreed to join Ingersoll and Jackson on February 1, and the local newspaper ran a notice announcing his participation. Although Kelly changed his mind on January 15, he took no action to prevent the publication of the notice or to inform the creditor of his withdrawal from the partnership. By extending credit to the firm based on the published notice, Creditor relied on the information provided, which included Kelly's implied agreement to join the partnership. Under the principles of partnership law, Kelly's initial agreement and the subsequent publication of the notice create an enforceable obligation for him to fulfill his partnership responsibilities, including potential liabilities, unless he can prove that he took all necessary steps to withdraw from the partnership and that Creditor knew of his withdrawal. Since Kelly did nothing to prevent the notice or inform Creditor of his change of heart, he remains liable as a partner for any obligations incurred by the partnership, including those of Creditor.

qa_pairs.question: What are the primary rationales behind the creation of hybrid business forms such as limited partnerships and limited liability companies?
qa_pairs.answer: The primary rationales behind the creation of hybrid business forms such as limited partnerships and limited liability companies are risk reduction and tax reduction. These hybrid forms allow businesspeople to reduce their risk while still retaining the potential for significant profit. qa_pairs.question: How does the governing law for limited partnerships evolve over time and what changes were introduced in the 2001 act?
qa_pairs.answer: The governing law for limited partnerships originates from the Uniform Limited Partnership Act (ULPA), drafted in 1916. This act was significantly revised in 1976, leading to the adoption of the Revised Uniform Limited Partnership Act (RULPA). The 2001 amendments to RULPA were made to address a changing business landscape where limited liability partnerships and limited liability companies could fulfill many of the roles previously served by limited partnerships. The 2001 act aimed to modernize the legal framework to better align with contemporary business practices and the advent of new entity types, ensuring that the law remains relevant and effective in supporting innovative business structures.

Definition 
A limited partnership (LP) is defined as “a partnership formed by two or more persons under the laws 
of a State and having one or more general partners and one or more limited partners.” [2] The form tends 
to be attractive in business situations that focus on a single or limited-term project, such as making a 
movie or developing real estate; it is also widely used by private equity firms. 
 
Creation and Capitalization 
Unlike a general partnership, a limited partnership is created in accordance with the state statute 
authorizing it. There are two categories of partners: limited and general. The limited partners capitalize 
the business and the general partners run it.

qa_pairs.question: What are the main differences between the Uniform Limited Partnership Act (ULPA) versions of 1976 and 2001?
qa_pairs.answer: The main difference between the Uniform Limited Partnership Act (ULPA) versions of 1976 and 2001 lies in their targeted enterprises and assumptions about the types of partnerships they aim to regulate. The 1976 act was drafted before the rise of limited liability partnerships (LLPs) and limited liability companies (LLCs), which could handle many of the functions previously served by limited partnerships. In contrast, the 2001 act was designed to address two specific types of enterprises that are less suited to LLPs and LLCs: sophisticated, manager-entrenched commercial deals and estate planning arrangements, such as family limited partnerships. These new assumptions led to a set of rules and default rules that emphasize strong centralized management and passive investment roles within the partnership.

qa_pairs.answer: According to the Uniform Limited Partnership Act (ULPA), a limited partnership (LP) is 'a partnership formed by two or more persons under the laws of a State and having one or more general partners and one or more limited partners.' The key roles in a limited partnership are those of the limited and general partners. Limited partners are primarily investors who contribute capital to the business but do not participate in its management, while general partners are responsible for managing the business and making day-to-day decisions. KEY TAKEAWAY 
 
The limited liability company has become the entity of choice for many businesspeople. It is created by state 
authority that, upon application, issues the “certificate of organization.” It is controlled either by managers or 
by members, it affords its members limited liability, and it is taxed like a partnership. But these happy results 
are obtained only if the firm lacks enough corporate attributes to escape being labeled as a corporation. To 
avoid too much “corporateness,” the firm’s certificate usually limits its continuity of life and the free 
transferability of interest. The ongoing game is to finesse these limits: to make them as nonconstraining as 
possible, to get right up to the line to preserve continuity, and to make the interest as freely transferable as 
possible.

was authorized by Congress in 1958 to help small corporations and to stem the economic and cultural 
influence of the relatively few, but increasingly powerful, huge multinational corporations. According to 
the website of an S corporation champion, “a half century later, S corporations are the most popular 
corporate structure in America. The IRS estimates that there were 4.5 million S corporation owners in the 
United States in 2007—about twice the number of C [standard] corporations.” [1] 
 
Creation and Capitalization 
The S corporation is a regular corporation created upon application to the appropriate secretary of state’s 
office and operated according to its bylaws and shareholders’ agreements. There are, however, some limits 
on how the business is set up, among them the following:

qa_pairs.question: What are the six attributes of a corporation and which two are typically not included in a Limited Liability Company (LLC)?
qa_pairs.answer: The six attributes of a corporation are perpetual existence, limited liability, centralized management, formalities, centralized decision-making, and transferability of ownership interests. In contrast, a Limited Liability Company (LLC) typically drops the requirements for centralized management and transferability of ownership interests to maintain flexibility and control over these aspects.

qa_pairs.question: How do Limited Liability Companies (LLCs) manage to avoid being treated like corporations while still maintaining certain advantages?
qa_pairs.answer: Limited Liability Companies (LLCs) manage to avoid being treated like corporations by limiting their continuity of life and the free transferability of interest through their certificate of organization. This approach allows LLCs to preserve the benefits of limited liability and pass-through taxation without fully adopting corporate structures. The ongoing game for LLCs involves fine-tuning these limitations to make them as non-constraining as possible, thereby striking a balance between retaining flexibility and avoiding excessive corporate characteristics.

Liability 
As noted, the purpose of the LLP form of business is to afford insulation from liability for its members. A 
typical statute provides as follows: “Any obligation of a partnership incurred while the partnership is a 
limited liability partnership, whether arising in contract, tort or otherwise, is solely the obligation of the 
partnership. A partner is not personally liable, directly or indirectly, by way of indemnification, 
contribution, assessment or otherwise, for such an obligation solely by reason of being or so acting as a 
partner.” [3] 
 
However, the statutes vary. The early ones only allowed limited liability for negligent acts and retained 
unlimited liability for other acts, such as malpractice, misconduct, or wrongful acts by partners, 
employees, or agents. The second wave eliminated all these as grounds for unlimited liability, leaving only 
breaches of ordinary contract obligation. These two types of legislation are called partial shield statutes. 
The third wave of LLP legislation offered full shield protection—no unlimited liability at all. Needless to 
say, the full-shield type has been most popular and most widely adopted. Still, however, many statutes 
require specified amounts of professional malpractice insurance, and partners remain fully liable for their 
own negligence or for wrongful acts of those in the LLP whom they supervise. 
 
In other respects, the LLP is like a partnership.

qa_pairs.question: How does the liability structure of an LLP differ from traditional partnerships, and what variations exist in the statutes governing LLPs?
qa_pairs.answer: An LLP is designed to provide protection against personal liability for its members' mistakes or malpractice. Statutes typically provide that any obligation of the partnership, whether contractual or tortious, is solely the responsibility of the partnership itself, and individual partners are not personally liable for such obligations. However, the statutes vary in terms of the extent of this protection. Early statutes provided limited liability primarily for negligent acts, but left unlimited liability for other acts such as malpractice, misconduct, or wrongful acts. Subsequent statutes expanded this protection to cover all acts except breaches of ordinary contractual obligations, known as partial shield statutes. More recently, some states have adopted full shield statutes, which eliminate all grounds for unlimited liability. Despite these differences, most statutes still require partners to maintain professional malpractice insurance and hold individuals fully accountable for their own negligence or for the wrongful acts of supervised personnel within the LLP.

qa_pairs.question: What is the principal disadvantage of the corporate form compared to a general partnership?
qa_pairs.answer: The principal disadvantage of the corporate form compared to a general partnership is that corporations impose double taxation, where both the corporation and the shareholders are taxed on profits. This contrasts with general partnerships, where profits and losses are passed directly to the partners, who pay taxes on them individually, avoiding double taxation.

qa_pairs.question: Why might a limited partnership not be the ideal solution to address the liability concerns of a traditional partnership?
qa_pairs.answer: A limited partnership may not be the ideal solution to address the liability concerns of a traditional partnership because while it limits the liability of the limited partners to their investment, the general partners still face unlimited personal liability. Additionally, the management structure can create conflicts, as the limited partners typically do not have significant involvement in the day-to-day operations and decision-making processes, which can lead to issues of moral hazard where the limited partners may not fully engage in risk management or oversight due to their limited role in the partnership's affairs.

qa_pairs.question: Under what circumstances can a member or manager of an LLC be held personally liable for the company's debts?
qa_pairs.answer: A member or manager of an LLC can be held personally liable for the company's debts if a provision for such liability is included in the articles of organization and the member or manager consents in writing to be bound by that provision. Additionally, if a member or manager acts after the dissolution of the LLC, they can be held liable for debts if the act is not appropriate for winding up the company's business or causes damage to the company. Furthermore, if a member or manager, knowing about the dissolution, subjects the LLC to liability through an act that is not for winding up the business, they can be held liable for damages caused to the company.

qa_pairs.question: If Topel's business had been structured as a corporation instead of an LLC, would he still have been insulated from liability for post-dissolution contracts?
qa_pairs.answer: No, if Topel's business had been a corporation, he would not have had the same insulation from liability for post-dissolution contracts. Therefore, in the scenario where Topel’s business was a corporation, he would have been liable for any post-dissolution contracts, unlike the situation with the LLC where the court found no personal liability for Topel due to the clear statutory language that protects LLC members from such liabilities.

qa_pairs.question: Given the current LLC act language being similar to the Model Business Corporation Act, which allows for piercing, why did the court decide not to pierce the LLC shield in this case?
qa_pairs.answer: The court’s decision not to pierce the LLC shield in this case was likely based on the strict interpretation of the statutory language provided by the LLC Act. Although the current LLC act language is similar to the Model Business Corporation Act, which permits piercing, the court was bound by the explicit provisions of the LLC Act. In this case, the court found that the Act does not authorize the piercing of the LLC shield for personal liability to third parties for an LLC’s debts and liabilities. This decision was made even though the plaintiffs argued that the circuit court’s ruling did not provide an equitable result. The court emphasized that the legislative intent was clear and that it could not override this through judicial interpretation, thereby affirming the judgment of the circuit court of Cook County.

In the mid-twentieth century, Congress was importuned to allow small corporations the benefit of pass-
through taxation. It created the sub-S corporation (referring to a section of the IRS code). It affords the 
benefits of taxation like a partnership and limited liability for its members, but there are several 
inconvenient limitations on how sub-S corporations can be set up and operate. 
 
The 1990s saw the limited liability company become the entity of choice for many businesspeople. It deftly 
combines limited liability for all owners—managers and nonmanagers—with pass-through taxation and 
has none of the restrictions perceived to hobble the sub-S corporate form. Careful crafting of the firm’s 
bylaws and operating certificate allow it to combine the best of all possible business forms. There 
remained, though, one fly in the ointment: most states did not allow professionals to form limited liability 
companies (LLCs). 
 
This last barrier was hurtled with the development of the limited liability partnership. This form, though 
mostly governed by partnership law, eschews the vicarious liability of nonacting partners for another’s 
torts, malpractice, or partnership breaches of contract. The extent to which such exoneration from 
liability presents a moral hazard—allowing bad actors to escape their just liability—is a matter of concern. 
 
Having polished off liability for all owners with the LLC and the LLP, the next logical step occurred when 
eyes returned to the venerable limited partnership. The invention of the limited liability limited 
partnership in ULPA-2001 not only abolished the “control test” that made limited partners liable if they 
got too involved in the firm’s operations but also eliminated the general partner’s liability.

qa_pairs.question: What are the roles and liabilities associated with general and limited partners in a limited partnership?
qa_pairs.answer: In a limited partnership, the roles and liabilities are distinctly divided between general partners and limited partners. General partners control the firm and have the same level of liability as a partner in a general partnership, except under the Uniform Limited Partnership Act (ULPA) of 2001 where liability is limited. On the other hand, limited partners are essentially investors who have minimal involvement in the day-to-day operations of the firm. Their liability is limited, meaning they can only lose the amount of money they invested in the partnership. However, if they become too involved in the firm's operations, they may lose their status as limited partners, although this rule does not apply under ULPA-2001.

qa_pairs.question: How does the creation of the sub-S corporation address the issue of pass-through taxation for small corporations and what are some limitations associated with it?
qa_pairs.answer: The sub-S corporation was created by Congress in the mid-twentieth century to provide small corporations with the benefits of pass-through taxation, similar to those of a partnership. This means that the profits and losses of the corporation are passed through to the shareholders' personal tax returns, avoiding the double taxation that typically affects C corporations. However, sub-S corporations face several limitations, including restrictions on the number of shareholders, who must be U.S. citizens or residents, and limitations on the types of businesses that can qualify for sub-S status. Additionally, sub-S corporations cannot have more than 100 shareholders, and they cannot issue different classes of stock.

Some companies were wildly successful. The British East India Company paid its original investors a 
fourfold return between 1683 and 1692. But perhaps nothing excited the imagination of the British more 
than the discovery of gold bullion aboard a Spanish shipwreck; 150 companies were quickly formed to 
salvage the sunken Spanish treasure. Though most of these companies were outright frauds, they ignited 
the search for easy wealth by a public unwary of the risks. In particular, the South Sea Company promised 
the sun and the moon: in return for a monopoly over the slave trade to the West Indies, it told an 
enthusiastic public that it would retire the public debt and make every person rich. 
 
In 1720, a fervor gripped London that sent stock prices soaring. Beggars and earls alike speculated from 
January to August; and then the bubble burst. Without considering the ramifications, Parliament had 
enacted the highly restrictive Bubble Act, which was supposed to do away with unchartered joint-
stock companies. When the government prosecuted four companies under the act for having fraudulently 
obtained charters, the public panicked and stock prices came tumbling down, resulting in history’s first 
modern financial crisis. 
 
As a consequence, corporate development was severely retarded in England. Distrustful of the chartered 
company, Parliament issued few corporate charters, and then only for public or quasi-public 
undertakings, such as transportation, insurance, and banking enterprises. Corporation law languished: 
William Blackstone devoted less than 1 percent of his immensely influential Commentaries on the Law of 
England (1765) to corporations and omitted altogether any discussion of limited liability. In The Wealth 
of Nations (1776), Adam Smith doubted that the use of corporations would spread. England did not repeal 
the Bubble Act until 1825, and then only because the value of true incorporation had become apparent 
from the experience of its former colonies.

qa_pairs.answer: The characteristic that above all led shareholders to subscribe to the stock was limited liability. Shareholders risked only the cash they put in, not their personal fortunes, which made it an attractive investment option.

qa_pairs.question: How did the British public's perception of risk and reward influence the formation of companies during the late 17th century?
qa_pairs.answer: The British public's perception of risk and reward was significantly influenced by the discovery of gold bullion aboard a Spanish shipwreck. This event ignited the public's imagination and enthusiasm for easy wealth, leading to the rapid formation of around 150 companies aimed at salvaging the sunken Spanish treasure. However, most of these companies were fraudulent, and the public was often unaware of the associated risks. Additionally, the South Sea Company promised to retire the public debt and make everyone rich in exchange for a monopoly over the slave trade to the West Indies, further fueling this optimistic view among the public.

qa_pairs.question: If the English Parliament had not enacted the Bubble Act in 1720, would the 'bubble' have burst? If so, what would have been the consequences to corporate development?
qa_pairs.answer: The enactment of the Bubble Act in 1720 by the English Parliament was aimed at curbing the proliferation of unregulated investment schemes known as 'bubbles.' While it is speculative to definitively state whether the 'bubble' would have burst without the Act, it is likely that the absence of such regulation could have led to a series of financial crises similar to the one that prompted the Act's creation. Without the Bubble Act, there might have been an increase in fraudulent practices, speculative bubbles, and market instability, which could have hindered the growth and trust in corporate entities. This could have delayed the development of a stable corporate structure necessary for economic expansion and industrialization. The lack of proper regulation might also have resulted in a lower level of investor confidence, affecting the overall economic environment and potentially stifling investment in new ventures. Consequently, the emergence and subsequent success of corporations in the late 18th and early 19th centuries might have been significantly impacted, possibly leading to a slower pace of technological innovation and economic development in England.

qa_pairs.question: What were some of the key components of early US corporate laws? What was the rationale behind these laws?
qa_pairs.answer: Early US corporate laws were characterized by significant restrictions designed to protect the public interest and prevent abuse. Key components included stringent requirements for registration, limited liability provisions, and strict regulations regarding stock issuance and management practices. These laws were crafted with the intention of ensuring transparency and accountability within corporate structures. For instance, corporations were required to provide detailed information about their operations, finances, and management to regulatory bodies. Additionally, the concept of limited liability was introduced to shield individual shareholders from personal financial responsibility beyond their investment in the company. The rationale behind these laws was to foster a stable and predictable business environment, reduce the risk of fraud and exploitation, and promote public trust in corporate entities. By imposing these stringent regulations, lawmakers aimed to balance the benefits of corporate organization against potential risks and ensure that corporations operated ethically and responsibly, thereby contributing positively to the broader economy and society.

Ownership and Control 
All general partners have equal rights in the management and conduct of the business. By contrast, 
ownership and control of corporations are, in theory, separated. In the publicly held corporation, 
which has many shareholders, the separation is real. Ownership is widely dispersed because millions of 
shares are outstanding and it is rare that any single shareholder will own more than a tiny percentage of 
stock. It is difficult under the best of circumstances for shareholders to exert any form of control over 
corporate operations. However, in the closely held corporation, which has few shareholders, the 
officers or senior managers are usually also the shareholders, so the separation of ownership and control 
may be less pronounced or even nonexistent.

unless all partners consent. The problem can be addressed and overcome in the partnership 
agreement. Transfer of interest in a corporation, through a sale of stock, is much easier; but for the 
stock of a small corporation, there might not be a market or there might be contractual restrictions on 
transfer.

qa_pairs.question: What are the primary tax implications of forming a corporation compared to a partnership?
qa_pairs.answer: Forming a corporation involves double taxation, where the corporation itself is taxed on its earnings, and then shareholders are taxed again on any dividends received. On the other hand, partnerships are subject to single taxation, meaning the income is passed through to the partners who report it on their personal tax returns without being taxed at the entity level. Additionally, corporations can take deductions for employee insurance coverage, which is not available to partners or sole proprietors.

qa_pairs.question: How does the corporate veil protect shareholders in a corporation?
qa_pairs.answer: The corporate veil is a legal concept that provides a layer of protection for shareholders in a corporation. It means that the corporation is considered a separate legal entity from its owners, shielding them from personal liability for the corporation's debts and obligations. This separation allows shareholders to invest in the company without risking their personal assets, as long as the corporation is managed properly and follows all legal requirements.
